Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Rational Design of Perfluoroalkylated N- and S-Containing Heteroaromatics for Engineering High Performance Air-stable OFET Materials with Lamellar pi-pi Stacked Structure
Award.AbstractNarration:
With the support from the Chemical Structure, Dynamics & Mechanisms B program in the Chemistry Division and the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program in the Division of Materials Research, Professor Haoran Sun at the University of South Dakota will lead this CAREER project aiming to 1) design, synthesize, and characterize perfluoroalkylated N- and S-containing heteroaromatic supramolecular synthons to prepare organic semiconductor materials with lamellar pi-pi stacked structure; 2) advance fundamental understanding of the correlation between molecular structure, weak intermolecular non-covalent interactions, solid-state structures, and device function; and 3) train students to solve complex problems in materials sciences. Professor Sun's research focuses on the synthesis and assembly of these perfluoroalkylated supramolecular synthons for low cost and high performance organic semiconductor devices for next generation electronics. The research team expects to identify these supramolecular synthons through both synthetic and computational approaches. During the project period, students at different levels will also be trained to learn skills for solving problems in materials sciences.

This project addresses one of the fundamental questions in developing next generation high performance organic semiconductor materials: how to design supramolecular synthons that can assemble into desired functional materials. A fundamental understanding of weak non-covalent intermolecular interactions is expected to have substantial impact on new organic functional materials design and to assist new drug designs. The multidisciplinary nature of this project will provide excellent training to students for solving complex problems important to today's materials chemistry. In addition to these exciting research activities, Professor Sun will continue to integrate cutting-edge research projects into undergraduate teaching for advanced chemistry major courses. The research group will work with local schools to organize educational outreach activities including "Coyote Science Education for Kids" and "Renewable Energy Workshop" for general public in local areas. The successful integration of research and education will provide the necessary workforce development and prepare students at all levels to develop skills for solving societal problems related to materials sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF CAREER project, led by Professor Haoran Sun at the University of South Dakota, focuses on answering a fundamental question associated with organic semiconductor materials: how to design new organic semiconductor materials that are high performance and stable.  Such semiconductor materials are key to the next generation of flexible electronic devices, for example, wearable sensors, flexible displays, and even large scale organic solar cells that can be produced on roll-to-roll bases.  To achieve this long-term goal, several important questions need to be answered.  Over the past six years, Professor Sun's research group has designed numerous fluorinated aromatic compounds as supramolecular synthons to prepare organic semiconductor materials with lamellar pi-pi stacked structure, one type structure of organic semiconductor materials that could result in better device performance.  The fluorination strategy further provides stability of PAHs, particularly against oxidative degradation. This research also advances fundamental understanding of the correlation between molecular structures and solid-state structures of fluoroorganic materials.  Such structure-property correlation provides general guidelines for scientists and engineers in the materials chemistry field to further develop new materials and devices with better performance and stability.  Throughout this project, Professor Sun's group has trained students at various levels, from postdoctoral and graduate students to undergraduate and high school students with much-needed skills in the STEM areas.  This project also helped gain a solid understanding of intermolecular interactions involving carbon fluorine bonds which has considerable impact on designing new materials.  In addition to its scientific impact, this NSF CAREER project has influenced positively on undergraduate education by integrating cutting-edge research into undergraduate chemistry teaching activities.  This successful integration offers students at all levels the problem-solving skills for materials sciences.
